text: Coffee is brewed from roasted seeds of the Coffea fruit.
Most global coffee comes from two species: arabica and robusta.
Coffee grows mainly in the Coffee Belt between the tropics.
Arabica often grows at higher altitude than robusta.
Robusta usually contains more caffeine than arabica.
Espresso is brewed by forcing hot water through fine grounds under pressure.
Decaf coffee still contains a small amount of caffeine.
For most adults, up to 400 mg caffeine per day is considered safe by FDA guidance.
A coffee cherry usually contains two seeds, which we call beans.
A peaberry is a cherry with one rounded seed instead of two flat seeds.
Coffee flowers are white and often smell like jasmine.
Coffee beans are seeds, not true beans from legumes.
Instant coffee is commonly made by spray-drying or freeze-drying brewed coffee.
Dark roasting reduces bean mass more than lighter roasting.
Grind size strongly affects extraction speed and flavor balance.
Cold brew is extracted in cool water over many hours.
Cappuccino got its name from the color of Capuchin robes.
Latte means milk in Italian.
Espresso crema forms from oils, dissolved gases, and pressure.
Freshly roasted coffee releases CO2 for days after roasting.
Water quality can change coffee taste dramatically.
Paper filters usually remove more coffee oils than metal filters.
Arabica is often described as sweeter and more acidic than robusta.
Robusta is often described as stronger, heavier, and more bitter.
Selective picking targets ripe cherries for better cup quality.
Brazil has been the largest coffee producer for many years.
Finland is often listed among the highest coffee consumers per person.
Coffee reached Europe through trade routes from the Arab world.
Ethiopia is widely cited as the origin of Coffea arabica.
The largest cup of coffee record is measured in tens of thousands of liters.
Roast level changes aroma compounds, body, and perceived acidity.
Burr grinders usually produce a more consistent grind than blade grinders.
Blooming coffee lets trapped CO2 escape at the start of brewing.
Caffeine half-life in adults often ranges around a few hours.
Storage away from heat, light, and moisture helps keep coffee fresher longer.
I like my mornings like my espresso: short and intense.
Decaf is just coffee trying to whisper.
My coffee and I have a latte trust issues.
I am not addicted to coffee. We are in a committed relationship.
Espresso yourself, but maybe after one cup.
I brewed a joke, but it came out too weak.
Coffee first. Adulting second. Maybe.
I told my mug a secret. Now it is full of beans.
Life happens. Coffee helps with the plot twists.
Today is sponsored by caffeine and optimism.
My blood type is probably espresso now.
A day without coffee is like... just kidding, I have no idea.
I cannot espresso how much this cup means to me.
Coffee understands me better than most meetings do.
I drink coffee for your safety.
No talkie before bean juice.
Coffee: because rebooting humans takes time.
My coffee is hot, my inbox is not.
Some call it chaos. I call it pre-coffee.
I asked for motivation. The barista said double shot.
The bean has spoken: one more cup.
I am fluent in espresso and mild sarcasm.
Coffee makes me almost pleasant.
I run on coffee, curiosity, and questionable plans.
If stress burned calories, my coffee would be sugar free.
I came, I saw, I made coffee.
My favorite exercise is lifting this mug repeatedly.
Coffee and deadlines: a classic pairing.
I do not need a therapist. I need fresh beans.
Bean there, brewed that.
First I drink coffee, then I do things.
I have a dark roast and a bright personality. Mostly roast.
Behind every successful task is a suspiciously empty mug.
Coffee is my favorite morning notification.
I am on a seafood diet. I see coffee, I drink it.
